DOC.brief_summary: In order to meet an existing lack of empirical studies in the field of cognitive behavioral therapy supervision, the present randomized controlled trial is aimed at comparing two different types of supervision. This study compares computer-assisted live supervision and delayed video-based supervision regarding efficacy and acceptance among therapists, patients and supervisors. The efficacy of supervision is defined on different levels such as change of psychotherapeutic competence, nondisclosure, self-efficacy, self-awareness of the supervisee as well as therapeutic alliance, supervisory alliance and therapy outcome.
DOC.brief_title: Acceptance and Efficacy of Live Supervision
DOC.criteria: Supervisees Having successfully completed the interim audit Having started to treat ambulant patients under supervision Patients Meeting ICD 10 criteria for a mental disorder Informed consent Currently in psychotherapy Suicidal tendency Clinical diagnosis of alcohol or drug addiction, acute schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder or bipolar disorder
